The monthly dividend stock


Code

dividends_df <- getDividends("DLR", 
             from = "1970-01-01",
             to = Sys.Date(), 
             env = parent.frame(), 
             src = "yahoo", 
             verbose = FALSE,
             split.adjust = TRUE,
             curl.options = list())

title: Warm welcome
text: This is just a file update

title: Inflation perspectives
About
text:
This is my little side project in order to learn some more coding. This website is created with Quarto, which is a great tool to make data public as well as combing R, Python and html code.
Learn more about Quarto here.

title: My personal portfolio
text: The KarambolageNed dividends

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Strategy
The strategy is easy: Safe and sound.
Generally, this portfolio has the purpose to add a signifcant amount of dividend income to the regular job income.

# Display the interactive plot

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Market Events and Performance
The performance of the S&P 500 is subject to various market events, including economic data releases, corporate earnings reports, geopolitical developments, and central bank decisions. Market fluctuations in the S&P 500 can have a cascading effect on other financial markets and impact investor confidence.

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Long term predictions
For this point, I want to demonstrate two scenarios:
-1. scenario: weak outlook and an average growth of 3% while adding 10k per year
-2. scenario: perfect wealth generation conditions with a growth of 10% while adding 10k per year
Let’s take a look at both:

scenario: growth 3% p.a., 10k additional investment from the job income


paste0(print("In year 2023 the portfolio has an income of 180k. Today the value is"))

[1] "In year 2023 the portfolio has an income of 180k. Today the value is"


[1] "In year 2023 the portfolio has an income of 180k. Today the value is"



scenario: growth 10% p.a. + 10k additional investment from job income

title: My personal portfolio
text: Long term predictions

title: The SP500
text: The SP500 index

title: The SP500
text:
Market Events and Performance
The performance of the S&P 500 is subject to various market events, including economic data releases, corporate earnings reports, geopolitical developments, and central bank decisions. Market fluctuations in the S&P 500 can have a cascading effect on other financial markets and impact investor confidence.
This is the distribution of the SP500. Scroll over the plot to get more detailed data.


Code
# Display the interactive 3D pie chart
fig






Code
print(paste("So it is nicely visible that the top 10 biggest companies by market capitalization are taking roughly", as.character(round(sum(sp500_df_top10$weight[1:10]),3)*100), "% of the cake."))


[1] "So it is nicely visible that the top 10 biggest companies by market capitalization are taking roughly 30.7 % of the cake."


Here is the chart of the SP500 since 1945:


Code
# Display the interactive plot
plotly_data






And this a plot of the performance of the last two years:


Code
# Display the interactive plot
plotly_data






It is also interesting to look at the logarythmic chart:


Code
# Display the interactive plot
plotly_data






```


Code
# Plot the data
ggplot(combined_data, aes(x = date, y = adjusted, color = Period)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "S&P 500 Performance Before and After COVID-19 Crash",
       x = "Date",
       y = "Adjusted Closing Price",
       color = "Period") +
  theme_minimal()





```

title: The SP500
text:
Conclusion
In summary, the S&P 500 is a crucial index that provides insight into the performance of the U.S. stock market and, by extension, the broader economy. Its composition, calculation methodology, and historical significance make it an essential tool for investors and analysts alike.
For up-to-date information on the S&P 500, please refer to reputable financial news sources and market data providers.

title: My personal portfolio
text: The KarambolageNed portfolio

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Strategy
The strategy is easy: Safe and sound.
Generally, this portfolio has the purpose to add a signifcant amount of dividend income to the regular job income.

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Market Events and Performance
Calculating the performance is tough since the money invested changes from to month due to the additional savings etc.

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Long term predictions
For this point, I want to demonstrate two scenarios:
-1. scenario: weak outlook and an average growth of 3% while adding 10k per year
-2. scenario: perfect wealth generation conditions with a growth of 10% while adding 10k per year
Let’s take a look at both:

scenario: growth 3% p.a., 10k additional investment from the job income







scenario: growth 10% p.a. + 10k additional investment from job income

This is the best case scenario.

title: My personal portfolio
text:
Additional thoughts
The goal is not retire as fast as possible. Live without work is damn boring.

title: Samsung Stock analysis
text:
Samsung stock
Samsung makes the best phones.


Code
chart_Series(SMSN.IL)

title: Olive oil vs. rape seed oil
text:
1 Olive Oil prices



 





This is a beautiful picture of olive oil. Yummy

An olive.


This dataframe has 403 rows now.
Here is the U.S. Dollars per Metric Ton of the FRED symbol “POLVOILUSDM” since 1990.


Warning: Can't display both discrete & non-discrete data on same axis


A line object has been specified, but lines is not in the mode
Adding lines to the mode...

Adding lines to the mode...




Olive oil price change since 1990




2 Rape seed oil prices

Let´s compare the olive oil price to the rapeseed oil chart (Ticker Symbol “PROILUSDM”):
Here is the U.S. Dollars per Metric Ton of the FRED symbol “PROILUSDM” since 1990.
